headline: GM to lay off 750 workers at Oshawa plant, citing U.S. tariffs: union president | CBC News
context: What we know about GM's layoffs in Oshawa
General Motors is laying off around 750 workers at its Oshawa Assembly plant as it makes changes to shifts due to U.S. tariffs, the president of the union representing workers said Friday.

annotations.paragraph: The plant, which employs roughly 3,000 people, is moving from a three-shift to a two-shift operation starting this fall, according to a news release from Unifor, which represents workers there.
annotations.reason: Explains the operational change triggering layoffs.

annotations.paragraph: "We will not allow GM to barter Canadian jobs to gain Donald Trump's favour," said Lana Payne, Unifor national president, in Friday's news release.
annotations.reason: Union leader’s statement framing the layoff motive.

annotations.paragraph: She called the move a "reckless decision that deals a direct blow to our members and threatens to ripple through the entire auto parts supplier network."
annotations.reason: Characterizes the broader impact per union leadership.

annotations.paragraph: Around 750 workers will be laid off at the plant, in addition to 1,500 people who work in other places throughout the supply chain, Payne told CBC Toronto.
annotations.reason: Quantifies total projected job losses directly and indirectly.

annotations.paragraph: GM spokesperson Marie Binette confirmed in an email the shift change "will impact approximately 700 workers," though she did not refer to the move as layoffs.
annotations.reason: Company response with a slightly different figure.

annotations.paragraph: "We are committed to supporting employees through the transition," she said.
annotations.reason: Corporate assurance of support measures.

annotations.paragraph: The layoffs come as workers in Oshawa's auto industry have been bracing for the impact of U.S. tariffs on their livelihoods. President Donald Trump slapped a 25 per cent tariff on all vehicle imports to the U.S. last month.
annotations.reason: Links layoffs to the broader context of U.S. tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: GM's Oshawa plant "will return to a two-shift operation in light of forecasted demand and the evolving trade environment," spokesperson Jennifer Wright said in an email to CBC Toronto on Friday.
annotations.reason: Provides official rationale combining demand and trade factors.

annotations.paragraph: "These changes will help support a sustainable manufacturing footprint as GM reorients the Oshawa plant to build more trucks in Canada for Canadian customers," she said.
annotations.reason: Explains long-term strategic rationale for shift reduction.

annotations.paragraph: The Oshawa plant assembles light and heavy-duty Chevrolet Silverado pick-up trucks for the North American market, which are also assembled at factories in the U.S. and Mexico, Unifor said.
annotations.reason: Details the plant’s production role in North America.

annotations.paragraph: GM has to provide six months notice of layoffs and that notice has now been issued, Payne told CBC Toronto.
annotations.reason: Explains legal requirement and its fulfillment.

annotations.paragraph: "I will use every day in those six months to fight back with our members to try and get General Motors to reverse this decision," she said.
annotations.reason: Union strategy statement for the transition period.

annotations.paragraph: Prime Minister Mark Carney offered his "deepest sympathy" for affected workers and their families during his first major news conference since winning the federal election.
annotations.reason: Government leader’s expression of sympathy.

annotations.paragraph: He said the government is "fighting hard" for the auto sector and is "making sure companies act in true partnership … in maintaining employment and investment in Canada."
annotations.reason: Carney’s pledge of government advocacy for industry.

annotations.paragraph: "If not, there will be consequences for those companies," Carney said.
annotations.reason: Warning of potential government action.

annotations.paragraph: Payne said General Motors jumped the gun by announcing shift cuts before Carney and U.S. President Donald Trump began talks on a new economic deal, calling the move "premature and disrespectful."
annotations.reason: Union critique of timing relative to political talks.

annotations.paragraph: Carney will meet Trump at the White House on Tuesday, multiple sources have confirmed to CBC News.
annotations.reason: Notes upcoming political meeting relevant to tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: Unifor called on the federal government to "review and reconsider" GM's tariff-exempt status under Canada's remission framework in Friday's release.
annotations.reason: Union’s policy recommendation to the government.

annotations.paragraph: This framework grants companies relief from paying retaliatory Canadian tariffs on products from the U.S., according to the government's website.
annotations.reason: Explains the remission framework mechanism.

annotations.paragraph: The union is also asking Carney to meet with automakers to reaffirm their commitment to Canadian investment and production.
annotations.reason: Additional union advocacy request for government-industry talks.

annotations.paragraph: Ontario Premier Doug Ford said the news is "extremely tough" for workers and their families in a post on X on Friday.
annotations.reason: Provincial leader’s reaction statement.

annotations.paragraph: "These are hard working people who have helped build Ontario's auto industry," he said.
annotations.reason: Characterization of the workforce by the premier.

annotations.paragraph: The premier said GM has "reaffirmed its commitment" to the Oshawa plant, adding that it will continue building Ontario-made trucks "for years to come."
annotations.reason: Ford’s claim of ongoing corporate commitment.

annotations.paragraph: "We will continue doing everything we can to support a strong future for the facility and its workers," Ford said.
annotations.reason: Further statement of government support promise.

annotations.paragraph: Meanwhile, the Stellantis assembly plant in Windsor, which employs roughly 4,500 people, is shutting down next week — though the company has not pointed to tariffs as the reason behind the closure.
annotations.reason: Reports a related plant closure with unclear cause.

annotations.paragraph: Ontario NDP Leader Marit Stiles called on Ford to deliver "a real plan" to keep auto jobs in Oshawa and Windsor in a statement Friday.
annotations.reason: Opposition leader’s demand for government action.

annotations.paragraph: "Ontario's auto workers built General Motors and our province invested heavily in Stellantis," she said in a news release.
annotations.reason: Context for her demand by referencing past investments.

annotations.paragraph: "We cannot just 'wait and see' while these companies take a page out of Trump's playbook and throw the future of thousands of workers and their families into chaos."
annotations.reason: Strong critique highlighting urgency of intervention.

annotations.paragraph: Thursday saw a moment of relief for the North American auto industry, as it was announced automobile parts that are compliant with the Canada-U.S.-Mexico Agreement (CUSMA) on trade are exempt from the 25 per cent tariff, according to U.S. Customs and Border Protection guidance.
annotations.reason: Notes related positive development for parts sector.

annotations.paragraph: The exemption means Canadian-made auto parts shipped directly to American assembly plants will not be subject to the tariff, said Flavio Volpe, president of the Automotive Parts Manufacturers' Association, in an interview with CBC Radio's Metro Morning on Friday.
annotations.reason: Industry leader’s explanation of the exemption benefit.

annotations.paragraph: If auto parts from Canada and Mexico were tariffed, the additional expenses could shut down supply chains and result in the "failure of the American auto industry," he said.
annotations.reason: Quote on potential catastrophic impact of comprehensive tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: But Payne said the new guidance "changes nothing" for the Canadian auto industry in Friday's news release.
annotations.reason: Union leader’s dismissal of the exemption’s benefit to Canada.

annotations.paragraph: "It is solely designed to keep U.S. factories running, because they rely heavily on Canadian made auto parts, while continuing to harm Canada's auto assembly plants," she said.
annotations.reason: Union critique focusing on unequal benefits.

annotations.paragraph: The union said GM intends to reduce Oshawa truck exports to the U.S. and recalibrate the plant for Canadian sales, starting in the fall.
annotations.reason: Reports GM’s adaptation strategy for the plant.

annotations.paragraph: "The question is … do Canadians buy those products in the same proportions as Americans do?" Volpe said.
annotations.reason: Valid question on domestic market absorption capacity.

annotations.paragraph: "When they don't, that's when you see shifts slip."
annotations.reason: Summarizes potential downside in one sentence.

annotations.paragraph: Close to 98 per cent of workers at the Oshawa plant were either laid off or went into retirement after GM closed the plant in 2019. Vehicle production resumed in late 2021.

annotations.paragraph: Canada is a large market for GM, Payne told CBC Toronto, as the company sold 300,000 vehicles in the country last year.
